entry.title: LeverX Early-Stage Experience With Joule Studio in SAP Build for Access Automation
entry.content:
LeverX Applies SAP Build and Joule Studio to Streamline Role and Authorization Requests

At LeverX, we believe the next stage of enterprise software is defined by intelligent workflows ‚Äî systems that understand context, interpret intent, and act independently.

We already used Joule Studio in one of our previous projects, where it significantly enhanced CAD data search for engineers at a manufacturing enterprise, helping them save up to four hours per week per engineer. Building on that positive experience, we used Joule Studio again to address another common challenge in large organizations: employees spending significant time requesting and managing access rights across multiple systems.

In this project, we applied Joule Studio to design an intelligent assistant that automates the process, helping employees create and submit access requests through a conversational interface while ensuring compliance with internal policies.

Exploring Intelligent Automation With Joule Studio

In our work with customers, we often see that business users spend more time on system administration tasks than on their actual work. One of the most time-consuming examples is access management ‚Äî requesting roles, obtaining authorizations, and waiting for approvals.

This process typically involves several steps and multiple people: an employee submits a request, a support specialist verifies it, clarifies details, and then manually creates a ticket in an external system. In global organizations, this back-and-forth can take hours or even days.

Recognizing the inefficiency of this process, we analyzed how it could be reimagined with SAP Joule Studio in SAP Build. The agent builder capability in Joule Studio allows developers to create AI agents that understand user intent, access business data, and trigger actions in connected systems. For us, that meant the opportunity to transform a multi-step, manual workflow into an intelligent, conversational experience capable of handling access requests in real time.

While our project focused on a simplified scenario, we designed it with production scalability in mind. In a live enterprise setting, the same approach could connect to various SAP systems and databases, making it possible to handle complex authorization processes across departments and regions.

We envisioned a workflow where users describe their needs in natural language ‚Äî ‚ÄúI need access to production planning data,‚Äù for example ‚Äî and the agent automatically identifies the required role, gathers details, and creates a structured ticket in the company‚Äôs system. Under the hood, this seamless interaction is driven by Joule Studio, SAP AI Core, and ServiceNow working together.

By extending our experience as early adopters of Joule Studio, we wanted to explore how conversational AI could reduce repetitive work, improve compliance, and simplify user experience across enterprise systems.

Inside Our Joule-Based Solution

Our goal was to leverage the agent builder in Joule Studio for access provisioning use cases. As soon as we got access to this new functionality in Joule Studio, we started developing a prototype of our intelligent assistant called Access Agent.

The Access Agent interprets employee requests, identifies the right roles and authorizations, and automatically initiates the ticket creation process. From the user‚Äôs perspective, it feels like chatting with a virtual assistant. Behind the scenes, it integrates multiple SAP BTP components into a single, cohesive workflow.

The image below illustrates the high-level architecture of our solution.

At the core is Joule Studio, which manages the conversational flow and connects to supporting services. The agent relies on SAP AI Core for reasoning and document grounding, with an S3 Object Store serving as a repository for structured data on roles and authorizations.

For this prototype scenario, the data, such as roles and permissions from SAP Digital Manufacturing, was loaded statically into the object store. In a production setup, the access database would be connected directly to the agent, allowing it to make real-time queries and retrieve up-to-date information. SAP AI Core orchestrates synchronization of the vector database and repository, including chunking and vectorization.

Each user interaction is processed through the LLM-based reasoning engine that interprets intent and invokes the right tools, whether retrieving documents, validating information, or calling an external API. For external operations, Joule Studio connects to ServiceNow, where access tickets are generated automatically once all details are collected. This ensures every request follows IT procedures without manual intervention.

We structured the development around three key layers:

  • User Interaction Layer: A conversational interface built in SAP Build where employees communicate naturally with the agent.
  • Intelligence Layer: Joule‚Äôs reasoning engine combined with the AI Core document repository containing descriptions of digital manufacturing roles and associated authorizations.
  • Integration Layer: API connection to ServiceNow for ticket generation, ensuring seamless process execution from request to confirmation.

In the image below, you can see how the Access Agent interacts with a user in a real conversation. The chatbot recognizes intent, asks clarifying questions, and guides the user toward creating a correct and complete access request ‚Äî all within a few conversational steps.

By combining Joule Studio‚Äôs AI-driven orchestration with SAP BTP‚Äôs integration capabilities, we created a scalable, flexible framework for automating access management workflows ‚Äî one that can be adapted to any organization with complex authorization structures.

What the Project Showed Us

Deploying the Access Agent showed how Joule Studio can streamline complex enterprise workflows while keeping interactions intuitive for employees. Requests for roles and authorizations that previously involved multiple steps and back-and-forth communications are now handled entirely within a conversational interface.

The agent accurately interprets user intent, guides employees through any missing information, and triggers the creation of structured access tickets automatically. This eliminates repetitive manual tasks for both employees and support teams, reducing delays and potential errors in the process.

One of the most valuable insights was how Joule Studio‚Äôs AI-driven orchestration adapts to real-world scenarios without requiring rigid scripting. The agent can dynamically follow different conversation paths, handle exceptions, and connect seamlessly to external systems like ServiceNow.

Looking Ahead: The Future of Intelligent Workflows

The project again showed how Joule Studio can transform complex, manual processes into intelligent, automated workflows. By combining conversational AI with deep SAP integration, the solution simplified access management, enhanced compliance, and demonstrated clear potential for operational efficiency gains.

Looking ahead, the same approach can be expanded to production-scale solutions that connect directly to SAP authorization databases and other enterprise systems. Similar agents could also support employee onboarding, training access, or IT asset provisioning, extending intelligent automation across multiple business domains.

entry.title: A Smarter Support Experience
entry.content:
Your support experience is evolving. Key changes and what you need to know.

As part of our ongoing efforts to make support from SAP smarter and easier for you, we have been piloting new ways to optimize the support experience and better connect you with the right channels and the right experts. We are excited to share that these improvements are now live. 

What‚Äôs changing 

As your entry point, the ‚ÄúGet Support‚Äù application has been enhanced to make it easier to create and manage your support cases. 

  • A clearer, unified navigation structure now guides you through case creation, with each step accessible from the left-hand pane. 
  • The detailed description field has been moved to the beginning of the process‚Äîhelping you provide important context earlier and improving the quality of AI-driven recommendations. 
  • Improved UI consistency and AI disclosure messages to make the interface more transparent, intuitive, and ready for future innovation. 

In particular, the Incident Solution Matching (ISM) service has been further enriched with generative AI (GenAI) capabilities. Based on the information you provide, the service compiles relevant solutions and summarizes them into a single, easy-to-read answer‚Äîcomplete with links to the original knowledge articles used. 

The GenAI feature is being rolled out to customers in phases, starting with a limited group and expanding over time. It includes a feedback option to continuously refine your experience. 

When you create a case, you may receive a recommended priority based on your case details. This helps guide your selection so your case can reach the right experts and most suitable support channel, helping to enhance the overall resolution time. You remain in full control and can always adjust the priority to reflect your business impact or urgency. 

 

New customer view in 'Get Support' application

Set up your case for faster resolution 

To help ensure your case reaches the right experts as quickly as possible: 

  • Write a concise title for the issue that states the key symptom. 
  • Use the detailed description section to provide evidence, error messages, recent changes, and attempted fixes. 
  • Select the correct system that is affected by the technical issue you want to report 
  • Select the most accurate product, function, or component. 
  • Clearly describe the business impact, along with any workarounds in place 
  • Keep your case updated if conditions change and add feedback if you adjust the proposed priority. 

Thank you for partnering with us as we continue to transform support from SAP into an experience that is smarter and more effective for you.

entry.title: Is ‚Äúnarrow‚Äù AI dead? The implications of SAP-RPT-1 for Business AI & Data Scientists
entry.content:
This week our team attended SAP TechEd in Berlin where SAP unveiled their latest foundation model called SAP-RPT-1 (read as ‚ÄúRapid-1‚Äù). Some further information on this announcement is given in A New Paradigm for Enterprise AI: In-Context Learning for Relational Data as well as their official paper published at this year‚Äôs NeurIPS conference ConTextTab: A Semantics-Aware Tabular In-Context Learner. It is available for exploration on the SAP-RPT-1 Playground.

We start with a short background information: ‚ÄúNarrow‚Äù AI is the SAP term for Machine Learning (ML) models trained on customer-specific data to fulfil a specific task (‚Äúforecast my sales for the next quarter based on the historic evolution‚Äù), in contrast to foundation models that offer out-of-the box transfer learning and are thus applicable to a wide range of tasks. Thus, introducing RPT-1 fits well to the SAP vision of introducing low-code solutions to enable business or non-data scientist users to quickly get up to speed with AI-powered business solutions that go beyond LLM capabilities.

The strategic messaging is clear ‚Äì custom or narrow AI models are no longer needed, as foundation models can fulfill the task just as well or better. But is this really the case?

In this blog post, we will try to give some important context on that announcement, based on our extensive experience with SAP and AI. In the next section, we‚Äôll address three key questions:

  • What are the strategic implications for SAP customers and Data Scientists?
  • What are some important shortcomings of the approach businesses and Data Scientists need to be aware of?
  • What does SAP-RPT-1 mean for me as a Data Scientist, and when should I (not) use it?

Foundation Models for Text vs. Relational / Tabular Data

Let‚Äôs start with some basics. Just like Large Language Models (LLMs) are ‚Äúfoundation models‚Äù that are pre-trained to generate text based on previous text blocks (‚Äúprompts‚Äù) on terabyte of text data, RPT-1 is a ‚Äúfoundation model‚Äù that is pre-trained on millions of different relational datasets to generate values for one or more cells given surrounding cells.

The idea is not new, as libraries such as TabPFN have garnered more and more attention over the last year, showcasing promising results. In fact, RPT-1 seems to be an enhanced version of the TabPFN architecture, extended especially with capabilities that allow it to (a) understand column names and (b) allow it to learn from text values within dataset cells. Coincidentally, TabPFN just yesterday announced version 2.5, claiming SOTA (state-of-the-art) on a couple of benchmarks as well ‚Äì sadly, the technical report does not allow a direct comparison between these two.

A short comparison between narrow AI, Generative AI (LLMs) and Tabular Foundation Models

 

The inherent advantage of this is clear: In the same way as an LLM learns basic rules of natural language and common knowledge from its vast amounts of (textual) data during training, RPT-1 learns important concepts of tabular data: dependencies between different columns and cell values, the importance of column names and, most importantly, it has most likely also understood what a sales or service order is, and that price usually depends on the quantity and item types. The idea is simple: we can mask out any cell in a table and have RPT-1 predict its value, requiring only a handful of example rows as context.

In such a way, RPT-1 can be understood similarly as a ‚Äúfew-shot‚Äù LLM prompting approach. If you ask an LLM to assign tickets to correct recipients given their textual contents, you would include some real-world examples and their desired recipients as few-shot examples. That would ‚Äúteach‚Äù the LLM which people exist, and which person is responsible for what ‚Äì all within a prompt, not requiring any training step.

For RPT-1, the handful of ‚Äúcontext‚Äù rows that you provide take over the role of these examples above, giving RPT-1 a glimpse on what your tabular data looks like and establishing boundaries for their task. You then ask it to predict outcomes (e.g. the time it will take a customer to pay his invoice, the category for a ticket, etc.).

The Strategic Vision of SAP-RPT-1

The advantages are obvious. In an ideal scenario, we no longer need to hand-craft complex AI models, spending weeks on iterating different approaches, running hyperparameter sweeps, and so on. That would further mean that we no longer need Data Scientists working in Python to package their models into REST APIs, just so that they can be consumed from our business apps running in CAP on Cloud Foundry. Instead, the ‚Äúnew‚Äù Data Scientists would focus on understanding stakeholder demand, preparing data sets and key features, and then implement the forecasting pipeline in CAP, simply accessing the available RPT-1 model via the SAP Generative AI Hub.

Moreover, this would enable forecasting scenarios without a large amount of training data ‚Äì which previously was impossible to realise as hand-labeling data is time-consuming and expensive.

However, a key factor remains: AI scenarios will require a business case behind them and this requires understanding how reliable the AI forecasts are, what value they create, and the associated costs. In our eyes, we still need Data Scientists that can translate business requirements and domain knowledge into inputs for foundation models, and more importantly evaluate / back-test how well such a foundation model works for a given use case, translating that into KPIs that business stakeholders can understand. If stakeholders are happy with the measured accuracy, we no longer have to spend months on hand-crafting a narrow AI model. But if for some reason the model does not work well, we need to know its limitations before moving it into production. In the same sense that Generative AI-based solutions for text require an evaluation strategy to measure if it works well enough, RPT-1 requires an example dataset to ensure it meets business demands.

What are the Shortcomings and Quirks of Tabular Foundation Models?

However, it is important to understand that this also comes with some of the inherent flaws of other foundation models (such as LLMs). It is important to note that some of these ‚Äúflaws‚Äù are not an issue with RPT-1 in specific, but instead a result of the contextual learning paradigm that also affected related models such as TabPFN.

Firstly, the lack of explainability. With the EU AI Act mandating strict rules for high risk areas ‚Äì such as credit ratings in a finance or banking context ‚Äì even traditional narrow AI models (Gradient Boosting) were often called a ‚Äúblack box‚Äù or ‚Äúimpossible to explain‚Äù. Yes, you would be able to leverage packages such as SHAP to calculate local feature impacts, but these would only ever provide an approximation. With relational foundation models such as RPT-1, this becomes even more infeasible: We have no way of understanding how a specific forecast comes into being. That will most likely rule out any applications in areas where explainable AI, calibrated probabilistic outcomes or bayesian modeling are currently used. Luckily, SAP has these items well on their roadmap, and we are curious on how post-processing steps and others can be used to address these concerns.

Secondly, the lack of reproducibility and sensitivity to data ordering. Yes, RPT-1 will provide the same outputs twice if given the exact same context and task. However, due to its spatial attention-based design, changing the order of columns will usually ‚Äì all else equal ‚Äì change the forecast! The same applies to rows ‚Äì it suddenly matters if I sort my context data by date, or by the associated user ID. As a side effect of this, having two samples with all features equivalent does no longer guarantee that their forecasts will be the same. See below for an example.

Forecast with samples in time order

Slightly changed forecast after minor re-ordering of the same rows

 

What‚Äôs even more important to note ‚Äì The column names have a huge impact on the forecasted values, as their name and description is a direct input to RPT-1. While this allows transfer learning and capturing concepts about what a ‚Äúprice‚Äù column means, it also requires Data Scientists to accurately name their columns, ideally similar to the description used by SAP systems. In that sense, Data Scientists will also need to do ‚Äúprompt engineering‚Äù on column names to find what delivers best results. In our experiences, it was not possible to inject domain knowledge (‚Äúless scooters will be rented at night‚Äù) into the forecast (yet). Maybe in the future we will get some type of system prompt for relational transformers in the future?

Huge changes by simply renaming the column names

 Even more importantly, RPT-1 embeds values inside categorical and textual columns. This means it should be able to capture ‚Äúsemantics‚Äù behind cell values, hopefully improving accuracies for tasks that rely (partly) on textual data. However, this means that Data Scientists now also need to experiment with how the categorical values are named ‚Äì even if the ID values are the same, mapping categorical values will change the forecast outcome. This is another quirk that will not apply to traditional narrow AI approaches.

Renaming categorical values from IDs to ‚Äúspeaking‚Äù names changes the forecast - Sometimes to the better, sometimes to the worse

 

Even more so, a critical flaw (that also bothers similar models as TabPFN) is the limited context window (roughly 2.000 rows stated in the paper and as available in the playground). In many cases, this is far smaller than the training data available, so it is now a challenge upfront to decide which rows/samples from the full dataset need to be passed in as context to the current prediction task. This can be especially limiting for high-cardinality classification tasks: It is no longer possible to pass examples for each of the 15.000 material groups as a context for example.

Additionally, RPT-1 is ‚Äúa single-table model‚Äù, which means that Data Scientists (for now) still need to ensure that this one table contains all relevant fields, including for example joining / aggregating data from linked tables. In that way, feature engineering across multiple tables is still a manual task, and requires good domain understanding. SAP has acknowledged that and is conducting research to include data from linked tables automatically.

Together with the issue mentioned above (row order matters), the Data Scientist now has to derive a heuristic on which historic data samples should be passed as context for each to-be forecasted sample! We have thus shifted the responsibility of Data Scientists from optimising models to optimising data, features, and taking care of context management ‚Äì in a similar fashion as we have to carefully select the prompt and context for LLMs, using approaches such as Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG). Maybe we can even borrow the same approach from RAG for tabular data and maybe call it TRAG for tabular retrieval-augmented generation. Existing samples are embedded with a specialised relational embedding model, and when forecasting new samples we first select the 100 most similar known samples and pass these on to RPT-1 as context.

In addition, cells are ‚Äúfilled‚Äù one by one, so forecasting a lot of values will still take a fair amount of time, prohibiting the use for edge devices or ad-hoc tasks that require rapid decisions. Especially on the playground, there is a hard limit on maximum predicted cells as well as a rather strict rate limit.

As per SAP (and coinciding with our first evaluation results), SAP-RPT-1 also currently only supports classification and regression, no matching, recommendation or timeseries regression tasks. While these are on the SAP roadmap, it may take some time to fully leverage these capabilities on the full range of tasks that narrow AI models today successfully cover. Just a curious example: When tasked with predicting a time stamp between two given samples, it suggested the time stamp one year ahead.

 

Hype vs. Reality: A (slightly) critical view into SAP performance claims

SAP has suggested that their relational foundation-model may reduce ‚Äúerror rates by a factor of up to two‚Äù, e.g. when it comes to forecasts around materials, even when compared to fine-tuned narrow AI models trained on their customer data. Sadly, the linked paper does not support these claims directly, so we feel like some context is needed.

In their paper, the authors compare classification and regression tasks against some hand-crafted models (LGBM, XGBoost, CatBoost and auto-ML solutions such as AutoGluon) on a variety of publicly available collections of datasets (Appendix A.2, Table 3). Note that the paper calls RPT-1 by its former name, ‚ÄúConTextTab‚Äù.

These datasets are:

  • CARTE ‚Äúhas the particularity of being made of tables with high-cardinality string[s].‚Äù, i.e. exactly the type of ‚Äúsemantic‚Äù dataset that RPT-1 is set to excel in.
  • OML-CC18 ‚Äúa machine learning benchmark suite of 72 classification datasets carefully curated from the thousands of datasets on OpenML‚Äù
  • OML-CTR23, ‚Äúa curated collection of 35 regression problems available on OpenML‚Äù
  • TabReD, ‚Äúa new benchmark of industry-grade tabular datasets with temporally evolving and feature-rich real-world datasets‚Äù
  • TALENT, ‚Äúan Extensive Dataset Collection: Equipped with 300 datasets, covering a wide range of task types, size distributions, and dataset domains.‚Äù. The suffix ‚ÄúTiny‚Äù means putting ‚Äúfocus on a subset containing 45 datasets that are representative of the overall performance of the baselines investigated in the original works‚Äù

The relevant Table from the ConTextTab paper

In this comparison, we can see that across all datasets RPT-1 has an average rank of 4.7 to 5.42 (depending on the hyperparameters used). Its skill seems to be mostly evident on the CARTE semantic benchmark, where it only slightly trails behind AutoGluon. On the other datasets, RPT-1 is usually in the midfield of scores. Based solely on these benchmark alone, traditional narrow AI approaches as well as modern AutoML solutions, even without pretraining, are still frequently beating RPT-1. The sole question remains ‚Äì What is the skill, time and compute required to derive a narrow AI model that beats the RPT-1 set baseline?

In that context, it is also important to check how these ranks evolve depending on the amount of available task-specific training data. Thankfully, the authors did this analysis as part of their paper, as shown below.Model accuracy vs. dataset size

 

As we can see, for a limited set of training data (<5k samples), pre-trained contextual models (such as RPT-1/ConTextTab, TabPFN) are the top contenders due to their ‚Äúgeneral‚Äù knowledge impacting forecasts. If limited training data is available, these models will almost always beat handcrafted narrow AI models. Beyond 5k samples, Auto-ML solutions such as AutoGluon or NN-based tabular learners such as RealMLP are the top models, with gradient boosting algorithms such as LightGBM catching up as more and more data becomes available.

When should I (not) use SAP-RPT-1?

Our generel recommendation: Always evaluate SAP-RPT-1 against known ground truth labels and against naive baseline models. For quick orientation, here are a few cases where we recommend using it ‚Äì and others where we don‚Äôt.

Use SAP-RPT-1 if:

  • training data is limited (less than 3-5k samples)
  • the task builds on columns that are commonly available in existing SAP systems, and training data is still somewhat limited (less than 10k samples)
  • the task heavily relies on semantic features, such as text values/descriptions, side by side with categorical data
  • you don‚Äôt care about the best model and getting 80% there with less effort works for you

Don‚Äôt use SAP-RPT-1 if:

  • you‚Äôre attempting time series forecasting, matching, recommendations, and the like
  • you have enough training data
  • reproducibility and explainability are a concern
  • you have to run without internet access / on edge devices, or do real-time forecasts on larger datasets

In general, we are extremely happy to see SAP leverage their experience with and vast amounts of available relational training data to provide the community with a promising new way to think about AI on relational data. Many of the shortcomings we currently see (and which thus reduce the scenarios where SAP-RPT-1 can be readily used today) are roadmap items and we are excited to see how these will be addressed and packaged into a well-rounded general purpose solution. In the long term, this has the possibility to enable Data Scientists with a less technical background to quickly deliver business value to stakeholders.

In that sense ‚Äì no, ‚Äúnarrow‚Äù AI is not (yet?) dead ‚Äì but relational foundation models will greatly change the way how we create business value with AI over the next two years.

entry.title: Creating custom Scalar functions in ABAP CDS
entry.content:
A CDS Scalar function ( This feature is supported as of SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS 00 ) allows us to define a custom function directly on SAP HANA database using SQLSCRIPT and then reuse it in CDS view entities.

There are 3 parts in CDS scalar function -

  1. A CDS scalar function definition ‚Äî this defines the Definition of Scalar function i.e, in and out parameters.   There will be one or many input parameters and exactly one output parameter.

Let's make this a CDS scalar function which will accept a date and returns respective weekday value( Mon, Tue, Wed, Thu, Fri, Sat ).

2. Define the CDS scalar function implementation reference. This refer to an AMDP class and method having the logic. This part won‚Äôt have actual implementation.

It follows the scalar function name followed by _SQL

Click on next and provide an AMDP class and its method which will hold the implementation logic.

3) Next, lets create our AMDP class (ZCL_AMDP_SF) and a static method (get_weekday).

Here below is the code for AMDP class and method.

CLASS zcl_amdp_sf DEFINITION
  PUBLIC
  FINAL
  CREATE PUBLIC .

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES if_amdp_marker_hdb.
    CLASS-METHODS get_weekday FOR SCALAR FUNCTION zcds_scalar_func.

  PROTECTED SECTION.
  PRIVATE SECTION.
ENDCLASS.



CLASS zcl_amdp_sf IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD get_weekday BY DATABASE FUNCTION FOR HDB LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT OPTIONS READ-ONLY.

    declare weekday_num int;
    weekday_num := weekday( input_Date );
    IF :weekday_num = 0 THEN result = 'MON'; END if;
    IF :weekday_num = 1 THEN result = 'TUE'; END if;
    IF :weekday_num = 2 THEN result = 'WED'; END if;
    IF :weekday_num = 3 THEN result = 'THU'; END if;
    IF :weekday_num = 4 THEN result = 'FRI'; END if;
    IF :weekday_num = 5 THEN result = 'SAT'; END if;
    IF :weekday_num = 6 THEN result = 'SUN'; END if;
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

 In the implementation , we have added logic to find the number as per input date and using if else logic , we are providing 3 char weekday name for same.

 

To test this, we have to create another CDS view which will call this CDS scalar function.

Let‚Äôs execute the CDS view to get output of Scalar function.

entry.title: Re: Error on candidate application when background Info a...
entry.content:
Hi @matteodavide ,

Option 1 ‚Äì Make background block ‚Äúread-only‚Äù for candidate

You can give candidates read-only permission to the background block (not to any individual fields).

  1. Go to Manage Templates ‚Üí Candidate Profile Template
  2. Locate the custom background block <background-element>
  3. Add candidate view permission:

<view-permission>

   <role-name>candidate</role-name>

   <field-permission type="read">

       <field id="*" />

   </field-permission>

</view-permission>

Why this works:

  • Candidate can ‚Äúsee‚Äù the block exists (technically),
  • but you can mask all fields using field-level permissions or hiding fields with ‚Äúread only‚Äù state.

You can configure read only + no labels, so the candidate sees nothing meaningful.

Option 2 ‚Äì Add at least one dummy field visible to candidate

You already tested this ‚Äî it works, but not ideal.
SAP accepts this as a workaround, but usually not recommended.

Option 3 ‚Äì Convert the background block to a ‚ÄúRecruiter-only‚Äù entity

Instead of a background block on the candidate profile, you can:

move these fields to Application Template ‚Üí Recruiter Only Fields Section

Example:

<field id="internalField" type="text" recruitOnly="true"/>

This way:

  • Candidates never see it
  • Recruiters can edit anytime
  • No dependency on Candidate Profile visibility

Recommended Approach: Option 1 (view permission on background block + hide all fields at the field level)
is usually the cleanest and SAP-supported way.

entry.title: Efficient Pagination in SAP CPI Using OData Services
entry.content:
Introduction

When working with large datasets in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI), pulling everything at once from an OData service can cause serious performance issues ‚Äî think timeouts, memory overload, and slow processing. That‚Äôs where pagination comes in. Instead of fetching all the data in one go, you break it down into smaller, manageable chunks. This approach keeps your integration flow efficient and reliable.

In this guide, we‚Äôll walk through a practical example using the Northwind sample OData service to show how pagination can make your life easier.

Step 1: Start with a Timer

Kick things off with a Timer-based trigger in your integration flow. Why? Because it lets you schedule the process to run automatically ‚Äî perfect for recurring tasks like syncing data every day or every hour. No manual intervention needed; just set it and forget it.

Step 2: Add a Looping Process Call

Next, you‚Äôll need a way to fetch data in chunks until everything is retrieved. That‚Äôs where the Looping Process Call comes in. It repeatedly calls the process to get the next page of data.

Here‚Äôs what to configure:

  • Condition Expression:
    ${property.Receiver1.OData.hasMoreRecords} = 'true'
    This tells the loop to keep running as long as there are more records to fetch.

  • Max Iterations:
    Set this to 10 (or tweak it based on how much data you expect). This acts as a safety net so the loop doesn‚Äôt run forever.

  • Action When Limit Reached:
    Choose Throw Exception. This ensures you have control if something goes wrong ‚Äî the loop stops instead of endlessly spinning.

Step 3: Modular Local Integration Process 

Within each loop iteration, invoke a Local Integration Process. This modular approach keeps your main flow clean and separates pagination logic for better maintainability.

Step 4: Configure the Request-Reply Adapter

Inside your Local Process, set up the Request-Reply Adapter to talk to the OData service. This is where you define how the data will be fetched.

Here‚Äôs what you need to do:

  • Adapter Type:
    Choose OData V2 ‚Äî it‚Äôs the standard for most SAP scenarios.

  • Authentication:
    For this demo, set it to None. (In real projects, you‚Äôll want proper authentication for security.)

  • Resource Path:
    Use Customers ‚Äî this tells the adapter which dataset to pull.

  • Query Options:
    Add $select=CustomerID,Address,City to fetch only the fields you need. This keeps the payload light and efficient.

  • Page Size:
    Set it to 3. This means you‚Äôll get three records per request instead of everything at once.

  • Process in Pages:
    Enable this option. It‚Äôs the magic switch that makes pagination work.

This setup ensures you‚Äôre pulling data in small, controlled batches ‚Äî reducing system load and improving overall performance.

Step 5: Content Modifier for Data Aggregation üóÇ

After each page fetch:

  • Use a Content Modifier to store the current payload.
  • Aggregate the results across iterations for further processing or output generation.

This step is crucial for building a complete dataset from paged responses.

Integration Flow at a Glance

Your flow will look something like this:

Timer
‚Üí Looping Process Call (handles pagination logic)
‚Üí Local Process Call (fetches each page)
‚Üí Request-Reply Adapter (OData V2 interaction)
‚Üí Content Modifier (aggregates results)

Key Things to Keep in Mind

  • The property
    ${property.Receiver.OData.hasMoreRecords} = 'true'
    acts as a flag to tell the loop whether more pages are available.

  • You can add a Filter Step to pull only the data you actually need from each page ‚Äî this keeps things clean and efficient.

  • Use the Content Modifier for aggregation. This ensures large datasets are handled in a controlled way without overwhelming your system.

SAP„ÅØ„ÄÅ„ÅäÂÆ¢Êßò„ÅÆSAP„É¶„Éã„Éê„Éº„Çµ„É´ID„Å´Èñ¢ÈÄ£„Åô„Çã„É≠„Ç∞„Ç§„É≥„Éó„É≠„Çª„Çπ„ÇíÂ§âÊõ¥„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Åì„Çå„ÅØ„ÄÅÂÖ®‰Ωì„ÅÆ„É≠„Ç∞„Ç§„É≥‰ΩìÈ®ì„ÇíÂêë‰∏ä„Åï„Åõ„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆ„Çà„ÇäÂ∫ÉÁØÑ„Å™Â§âÈù©„ÅÆ‰∏ÄÁí∞„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ

entry.title: Enterprise Generative AI and Governance in SAP
entry.content:
Artificial Intelligence isn‚Äôt something futuristic anymore it‚Äôs already here, designing how businesses work every day. SAP has been quick to adopt this change by adding Generative AI features through tools like SAP AI Core, SAP AI Launchpad, and the SAP Generative AI Hub.

These tools help companies use AI securely and responsibly. But as AI becomes more powerful, it also needs proper governance to make sure data stays safe, results are reliable, and everything is used in an ethical way.

In this post, let‚Äôs explore how SAP combines the power of Generative AI with smart governance to help businesses innovate confidently.

What is Generative AI in SAP?

Generative AI in SAP simply means using advanced models (like large language models) that can understand and generate content whether that‚Äôs text, insights, or suggestions based on real business data.

You will find it in action in places like:

  • Chatbots for customer support
  • Automatic report generation
  • Predictive maintenance
  • Employee self-service portals

SAP enables all this through AI Core and AI Launchpad, which connect these models to real systems such as S/4HANA, MDG, or SAP Datasphere.

The Big Picture: SAP‚Äôs Enterprise AI Architecture

If we zoom out, the Generative AI setup in SAP can be viewed in three layers:

  1. Data Layer ‚Äì This is where all the clean, governed, and reliable business data lives.
  2. AI Layer ‚Äì The acts as brain that processes and manages AI models.
  3. Application Layer ‚Äì The part users actually see apps, dashboards, or assistants that use AI insights.
  1. AI Model Lifecycle in SAP

AI models are not one-and-done projects. They need to be developed, deployed, monitored, and improved over time.

In SAP setup the process usually looks like this:

 

  1. Develop ‚Äì Train or fine-tune a model using relevant business data.
  2. Deploy ‚Äì Move it into production through SAP AI Core.
  3. Monitor ‚Äì Keep an eye on accuracy, performance, and compliance.
  4. Update ‚Äì Refresh or retrain the model as new data or business needs emerge.

This continuous cycle make sure that AI models stay useful, accurate, and secure. 

Why Governance Matters

Governance is what keeps AI on the right track. SAP focuses on three main principles here .

It ensures that:

  • Only clean and approved data is used for training.
  • Model outputs can be explained and audited.
  • Legal and ethical standards are always met.

Think of governance as the safety net that allows businesses to innovate with confidence instead of risk.

A Real Example: AI-Powered Sales Assistant

Imagine you are a part of a sales team using an AI assistant inside SAP Fiori.

You type a customer‚Äôs name and within seconds it gives you key details, suggests pricing, and even drafts a response email for it.

Here‚Äôs what is happening behind the scenes:

  • MDG provides clean and accurate customer data.
  • AI Core processes your request with Generative AI.
  • The AI assistant presents it in a clear, user-friendly interface.
  • Every step is logged for security and compliance.

The result?

There is less manual work, faster decisions, and more time to focus on actual selling.

My Final Conclusion:

Generative AI in SAP is transforming how businesses run making systems smarter, faster, and more intuitive.

But innovation alone isn‚Äôt enough. To really make AI work for the long run, companies need to have solid data governance and a clear AI lifecycle in place.

When these two go together, AI stops being just a tech it becomes a true business advantage.                                 

                                                                                                                                                 Published by

                                                                                                                                                  Nikhat Fatima

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC): A Beginner's Guide - Part 1
entry.content:
Introduction

Let's understand what is SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is a unified data platform which means a single environment that harmonizes information from all SAP and non-SAP sources into a trusted semantic layer. BDC can be the organization's single source of truth which provides a consistent, governed layer of data that everyone can use, whether it‚Äôs for analytics, planning, or building AI Applications. 

 

But the bigger topic is why do we even need something like SAP Business Data Cloud?

Why do we need Business Data Cloud? 

Today every organization is talking about being ‚Äòdata-driven.‚Äô We all want to make decisions based on real insights rather than gut feeling.  But in reality, its not that easy. the truth is data is everywhere. But it's rarely in one place or in one consistent format. Businesses have information scattered across multiple systems . Like some in SAP applications like S/4HANA or SuccessFactors, some in non-SAP platforms, spreadsheets, or even external sources like partners and IoT devices. So when companies try to bring that data together for analytics or AI, they face a few very real challenges.

  1.  How do you build a single, complete data foundation that supports modern AI and machine learning models?
  2.  How do you trust your data? how do you ensure quality, consistency, and integrity so that the decisions you make are actually reliable?
  3.  How do you extract real business value from this massive, mixed pool of structured and unstructured data?

SAP recognized that these are the exact pain points stopping companies from truly using data to their advantage. And that‚Äôs what led to the creation of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC).

One of the major innovations behind BDC is how it eliminates data fragmentation. Instead of moving data between systems and losing context along the way, BDC integrates data in real time while preserving its business meaning. For example, if the same business entity, say a customer exists in multiple SAP systems, BDC brings together under a unified definition using the One Domain Model. So business users don't have to worry about where the data came from or how it's structured. They simply work with consistent, harmonized business entities that are ready for analytics, reporting, or Artificial Intelligence (AI). 

The best part is SAP fully manages the entire lifecycle. BDC is delivered as a Software-as-a-Service solution built on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).  Because of that all the integration, replication, and governance are handled by SAP. In the past, customers had to manually extract and prepare SAP data before it was usable for analytics. That process was slow, expensive, and error-prone. With BDC, that‚Äôs all automated so organizations can focus their time and resources on building innovative AI models, automating insights, or improving business performance instead of just wrangling data.

Let's take a practical scenario, imagine a large enterprise with data coming from ERP, HR, procurement, and expense systems. Traditionally, every system had its own data units, and teams had to spend weeks just preparing the data before running any kind of analysis. Now, with SAP Business Data Cloud, all of that data whether it‚Äôs from SAP S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, Ariba, Concur, or even non-SAP systems can be harmonized and made available in one place instantly. That gives the business a 360-degree view across operations, employees, customers, and suppliers. The platform supports a wide range of use cases from data warehousing and BI, to AI and machine learning, planning, governance, and even intelligent application development. Basically, it‚Äôs an end-to-end solution that connects data and intelligence across the entire organization. The real value, however, is in the trust and governance that come built-in. Because BDC leverages SAP‚Äôs domain expertise and semantic understanding of business data, it ensures that what you see in your reports and AI models actually reflects reality not inconsistent or duplicate information.

So to sum it up, SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) transforms how organizations manage and use their data. It addresses the three biggest challenges of the data-driven world:

  1.  Building a single, reliable foundation for AI and analytics
  2.  Ensuring data trust and quality
  3.  Unlocking the full value of structured and unstructured data across the enterprise

It's like a bridge that connects all the data sources, both internal and external into one governed, business-ready environment. In other words, it takes us from data chaos to clarity. It helps organizations move beyond just having data, to truly using it to drive growth, innovation, and intelligent decision-making.

Key Components of SAP Business Data Cloud

Let's see how BDC is built and how the key components that make it work and how they fit together.

One of the most interesting things about SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is that it doesn't start from scratch. It combines some of SAP's most proven existing technologies with brand new innovations designed for the data and AI era.

Let's understand the existing SAP solutions that form the foundation. 

SAP Datasphere - This is one of the core data integration and modeling layer of BDC.  It is like a brain that organises, connects, and models all the business data. Datasphere allows you to define data models, map relationships, and create semantic layers that business and technical users can both understand. It‚Äôs the part of the platform that ensures data is structured, contextualized, and ready to use for analytics and AI.

SAP Analytics Cloud - This is the analysis and visualization layer. It‚Äôs where users actually interact with data through dashboards, reports, and planning models. SAC is tightly integrated with BDC.  It provides both out-of-the-box analytical stories and flexible tools for ad-hoc analysis. It even supports AI-driven features like predictive insights and chat-based data exploration, helping users move seamlessly from insight to action.

SAP BW or BW/4HANA -  Many customers already have large investments in BW, and SAP recognized that value. So instead of replacing it, BDC integrates it. BW data objects can be technically onboarded into the Business Data Cloud, as data products and reuse them in new AI and analytics scenarios. SAP plans to support BW until 2030, but the idea is to give customers a smooth modernization path toward BW/4HANA and cloud-native analytics.

Now let's understand the new components introduced specifically for SAP Business Data Cloud. 

SAP Databricks - This is one of the biggest innovations. It brings advanced AI and machine learning capabilities directly into the SAP ecosystem. Databricks has long been a leader in large-scale data processing and pro-code data science, and SAP has now embedded a tailored version inside BDC.
This integration allows data scientists to access and extend data products directly. For example, they can take a data product from SAP Business Data Cloud, enrich it with machine learning models in Databricks, and then push the enhanced insights right back into the BDC catalog or vice versa.

SAP Business Data Cloud Foundation Services - This layer manages the data lifecycle from ingestion and harmonization to transformation and enrichment. When data comes from your source systems (for example, SAP S/4HANA Cloud or SAP SuccessFactors) the Foundation Services replicate it into the BDC environment, which runs on SAP HANA Cloud and hyper-scaler infrastructure. From there, it‚Äôs automatically cleansed, harmonized, and turned into something called a data product which a packaged, ready-to-use set of business data.

Conclusion

Now we have covered the Introduction, Why do we need Business Data Cloud, and Key Components of SAP Business Data Cloud. I hope you have got a basic understanding about SAP Business Data Cloud. This is the first part of the blog series.

In the upcoming parts, we will cover the architecture of SAP Business Data Cloud, and understand the main components of BDC in detail.

If you have any questions or queries, please post them as comments. I will try to answer the maximum as per my knowledge.

entry.title: Re: Change Special Procurement in MRP view of material
entry.content:
Hi,

Hope you read help documentation else strongly recommend you to read once:

Special Procurement 20 - Direct Procurement

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ERP/85d3fce10e264972a0155c8b46ecf93b/1bacce5314894208e10000000a174cb4.html 

Special Procurement 70 - Withdrawal from alternate plant

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ERP/85d3fce10e264972a0155c8b46ecf93b/67acce5314894208e10000000a174cb4.html

In case of 20, you are procuring the component and storing & issuing from the same plant. In MRP run, necessary stock reservation and if required Purchase requisition is created.

In case of 70, the component is issued from another plant. When you run MRP, this component is not planned in MRP run plant but planned in the issuing plant (a reservation is created in issuing plant & when you run MRP in that plant, it creates planned order or purchase requisition as per material master). Typically done when both plants are in same location. Different plants might have been created at same location for some reason (tax/reporting/SBU design).  This type is used in such cases to avoid creation & execution of stock transport order.

Trust this helps

entry.title: Integrating Platform Events using Salesforce PubSub Adapter in SAP Cloud Integration
entry.content:
In this post, we will explore how to use the Salesforce PubSub adapter in SAP Cloud Integration (SAP CI) to subscribe to Platform Events in Salesforce. This approach enables real-time, event-driven communication between Salesforce and external systems without the need for frequent polling or API calls.

What is the Salesforce PubSub Adapter (Sender)?

The Salesforce Pub/Sub Sender Adapter uses the Pub/Sub API, built on the gRPC protocol. It allows SAP CI to listen to Salesforce event streams in real time. Instead of polling for changes or using REST API calls, this adapter maintains a persistent connection to Salesforce‚Äôs event bus, capturing events as they occur.

What are Platform Events?

Platform Events in Salesforce provide an event-driven mechanism to exchange data inside and outside Salesforce in real time. Instead of continuously querying Salesforce for changes, external systems like SAP CI can subscribe to Platform Events and react immediately when specific business conditions occur. This results in faster, cleaner, and more scalable integrations.

The true power of Platform Events lies in their ability to capture only the relevant business signals. Unlike Change Data Capture, which publishes every record change, Platform Events allow you to include only required fields, apply qualification rules, and fire events only when specific business conditions are met. This ensures cleaner, lighter, and more meaningful integrations ‚Äî especially in event-driven scenarios where SAP CI needs to react only to critical events rather than process noise.

Creating a Platform Event in Salesforce

Let‚Äôs create a sample Platform Event for the Account object. This event will send qualified Account data.

  1. Navigate to Setup ‚Üí Quick Find ‚Üí Platform Events ‚Üí New Platform Event.
  2. Fill in the details:
      ‚Ä¢ Singular Label: AccountPlatformEvent
      ‚Ä¢ Plural Label: Accounts
      ‚Ä¢ API Name: AccountPlatformEvent__e
      ‚Ä¢ Description: Event to send qualified Accounts to External system.
      ‚Ä¢ Leave default retention (72 hours).
  3. Create required custom fields (example):
      ‚Ä¢ AccountId__c ‚Äì Text(18)
      ‚Ä¢ Name__c ‚Äì Text(255)
      ‚Ä¢ Industry__c ‚Äì Text(50)
      ‚Ä¢ Rating__c ‚Äì Text(50)

These fields define the schema of your event messages.

Publishing Platform Events Using Apex

Next, we will publish the Platform Event whenever an Account record is created or updated. Below is a sample Apex trigger that publishes an event message, it can be created from Developer console of the Salesforce.

trigger AccountPlatformEventPublisher on Account (after insert, after update) {
    List<AccountPlatformEvent__e> events = new List<AccountPlatformEvent__e>();
    for (Account acc : Trigger.new) {
        events.add(new AccountPlatformEvent__e(
            AccountId__c        = acc.Id,
            AccountSource__c    = acc.AccountSource,
            AnnualRevenue__c    = acc.AnnualRevenue,
            BillingCity__c      = acc.BillingCity,
            BillingCountry__c   = acc.BillingCountry,
            BillingStreet__c    = acc.BillingStreet,
            CreatedDate__c      = acc.CreatedDate,
            CurrencyIsoCode__c  = acc.CurrencyIsoCode,
            Industry__c         = acc.Industry,
            IsDeleted__c        = String.valueOf(acc.IsDeleted),
            LastModifiedDate__c = acc.LastModifiedDate,
            Name__c             = acc.Name,
            Rating__c           = acc.Rating,
            SAPCustomerNumber__c= acc.SAPCustomerNumber__c
        ));
    }
    if (!events.isEmpty()) {
        Database.SaveResult[] results = EventBus.publish(events);
        System.debug('Published ' + results.size() + ' Account events.');
    }
}

Subscribing to Platform Events Using the PubSub Adapter

Once the Platform Event is created, configure the Salesforce Pub/Sub Sender adapter in SAP CI to subscribe to the event channel. Below are key features and configuration parameters:

  • Subscribe to Salesforce channels to receive events.
  • Supports publishing of events to channels with defined schemas.
  • Retrieve schemas using the 'Get Schema' operation.
  • Support for OAuth 2.0 Username-Password and OAuth 2.0 JWT Bearer authentication.
  • Replay options to control event retrieval (Earliest, Latest, Custom).
  • Error handling and re-subscription mechanisms.

 Below is the detailed description of each parameter used in this iflow covering Salesforce PubSub adapter.

We are using sender Salesforce PubSub adapter to consume the platform events, configurations are as below.

SAP CI Iflow:

Sender : Pick a sender from the pallet and select the Salesforce Pub Sub Adapter from the adapter list

Configuration of Salesforce Pub Sub Sender Adapter:

Parameter Description:

Host

Specify the host to which the proxy requests are sent for the gRPC API (towards the gRPC host). The proxy requests to the gRPC host will go through the proxy. Example: api.pubsub.salesforce.com

Port

Specify the port to which the proxy requests are sent for the gRPC API (towards the gRPC port). The proxy requests to the gRPC port will go through the proxy. Example: 7443

Tenant ID

Specify the Salesforce Organization ID, this can be found in Company Information within the "Setup" page on Salesforce

Authentication

Select the authentication type to be used for the connection to Salesforce:

  • OAuth 2.0 Username-Password
  • OAuth 2.0 JWT Bearer
‚ÑπÔ∏èThe following fields are available when OAuth 2.0 JWT Bearer is selected.

Token URL

Specify the login endpoint to your Salesforce instance url. Example: https://login.salesforce.com for Salesforce production environment, https://test.salesforce.com for Salesforce Sandbox environment and https://{MyDomain}.my.salesforce.com in case MyDomain is enabled on the org.

Credential Name

Specify the User Credentials storing the username-password details.

Security Token Alias

Specify the Security Token Alias that refers to the secure parameter.

This can be omitted if your SAP CI IP address has been whitelisted in Salesforce

OAuth Credential Name

Specify the User Credentials that stores the Consumer key-Client secret pair.

‚ÑπÔ∏èThe following fields are available when OAuth 2.0 JWT Bearer is selected.

Audience

Specify the login endpoint to your Salesforce instance URL. Example: https://login.salesforce.com for Salesforce production environment, https://test.salesforce.com for Salesforce Sandbox environment, and https://site.force.com/customers if implementing for an Experience Cloud site

Subject Alias

Specify the Secure Parmeter that stores the username of the Salesforce user.

Issuer Alias

Specify the Secure Parameter which indicates the OAuth client_id of the connected app in Salesforce for which the certificate was registered.

Keystore Alias

Specify the alias name of the added JKS file in Keystore as a Key Pair. It consists of a key and certificate to sign the JWT

Expiration (in ms)

Specifies the validity of the assertion in milliseconds

 Processing Tab:

 

Channel NameSpecify the Salesforce channel name to perform the subscription. (here we will use the /event/ and then the API name of the Platform event created in previous steps in Salesfoce.)
Replay ID Approach

Select the replay option in the first FetchRequest:

  • Events from a specific position (Custom) 
  • Events from earliest position (Earliest) ‚Ä¢
  • Events from latest position (Latest) The default value is Events from latest position (Latest) which allows subscription only to new event messages and does not retrieve earlier event messages stored in the event bus

Replay ID

Specify the Replay ID value. The Replay ID is populated by Salesforce and refers to the position of the event in the event stream. Example: 8381402

Request Batch Size

Specify the number of events to be requested in the Salesforce fetchRequest. The default value is 100

Replay Preset for Invalid Replay ID

Select the replay option in case ‚Äúsfdc.platform.eventbus.grpc.subscription.fetch.replayid.corrupted‚Äù error occurs:

  • Events from latest position (Latest)
  • Events from earliest position (Earliest) The default value is Events from earliest position (Earliest) indicating the earlier event messages stored in the event bus.

Duplicate Check Expiration (in ms)

Specify the expiry time in milliseconds while handling the Duplicate check. The default value is 300000

Process Errors as an Event

Enable this property to write error events in the exchange. If disabled, issues connecting to event streams will only be written to the logs

Deployment of the IFlow:

Now lets deploy the IFlow and see how this works, For demostration, I will create the Account record and then update it.

Demo:

New account created in Salesforce:

As soon the record is saved in the Salesforce, the event/message is generated which is received by SAP CI

{
  "payload": {
    "AccountId__c": "001J100000X6REOIA3",
    "AnnualRevenue__c": 10000,
    "CurrencyIsoCode__c": "USD",
    "Name__c": "Test Account For Demo",
    "BillingCountry__c": "India",
    "Industry__c": "Finance",
    "AccountSource__c": null,
    "CreatedDate__c": 1760449971000,
    "CreatedById": "0055g00000AqVaAAAV",
    "SAPCustomerNumber__c": "101",
    "CreatedDate": 1760449971276,
    "BillingStreet__c": "ABC Road",
    "LastModifiedDate__c": 1760449971000,
    "Rating__c": "Warm",
    "IsDeleted__c": "false",
    "BillingCity__c": "Pune"
  },
  "schemaId": "3lrXZmbw8vDsOdsDj74Qpw",
  "id": "644d0292-d8b7-4fd4-9c5d-5f64eefb7bca"
}

Now lets update the Account and see the event, I will update the name and the City

New event received in SAP CI

In order to see the replay Id of the event we need to check the headers after the Salesforce PubSub adapter step:

Replay Id when Account was created:

Replay Id of the update event:

Observations

  • Only the fields defined in the Platform Event schema are included in the payload. 
  • Each update triggers the transmission of the complete message again.

Conclusion

Using Salesforce Platform Events with the SAP CI PubSub adapter enables truly event-driven integrations between Salesforce and external systems. By defining only the necessary fields and publishing them through an Apex trigger, you ensure that downstream systems receive lean, relevant data instead of full records. The Pub/Sub adapter maintains a persistent gRPC connection for real-time delivery, minimizing API usage and latency. This approach provides a scalable, reliable, and modern integration pattern for enterprise-grade Salesforce-to-SAP scenarios.

Thanks,

Manish Deshpande

entry.title: Re: Is there a way to include values from multiple models...
entry.content:
@tsuuuu 

1. You have to use the "add existing dimension table" option to include the public dimension in both your models Model 1, and Model 2.

entry.title: When ‚ÄúAdd Columns‚Äù Broke My Brain: Basic CAP + BAS + Fiori Elements
entry.content:
1 ‚Äì Setting the Scene

I spun up a new CAP project in SAP Business Application Studio and thought:
‚ÄúHow hard can it be to show a list of incidents from a SQLite database?‚Äù

IncidentManagementCAP/
‚îú‚îÄ db/schema.cds
‚îú‚îÄ srv/incidentsrv.cds
‚îî‚îÄ package.json

schema.cds defined the usual suspects ‚Äî Incidents, Customers, Status, Urgency.
incidentsrv.cds exposed them through an IncidentService.
SQLite was configured as persistence.

2 ‚Äì CAP‚Äôs Circle of Errors

Act 1:

[ERROR] Mismatched ‚ÄπIdentifier‚Ä∫, expecting ‚ÄπString‚Ä∫

BAS had ‚Äúhelpfully‚Äù converted my straight quotes into curly ones. Replacing them with normal ASCII quotes fixed it.

Act 2:

no such table: IncidentService_Incidents

I‚Äôd only deployed the db model, not the srv one, so the projection view didn‚Äôt exist. Adding this to package.json fixed it:

{
  "cds": {
    "requires": {
      "db": {
        "kind": "sqlite",
        "credentials": { "database": "db.sqlite" },
        "model": [ "db", "srv" ]
      }
    }
  }
}
cds deploy --to sqlite

Act 3: BAS uses an in-memory SQLite DB by default, so every restart wiped my tables. Pointing to a real file finally made data persist.

3 ‚Äì Success (Sort of)

/> successfully deployed to db.sqlite

and:

IncidentService_Incidents
sap_capire_incidents_Incidents

Progress! I opened the preview app expecting rows of data ‚Ä¶ and got a pristine white screen reading:

Add columns to see the content

Nothing wrong with my code; Fiori Elements was just hiding every field until I manually selected them.

4 ‚Äì The Real Fix

  1. In the Data Preview, click the ‚öôÔ∏è gear icon.
  2. Choose Table Settings ‚Üí Columns.
  3. Tick ID, title, status_code, urgency_code.
  4. Click Apply.

Suddenly the data appeared ‚Äî the record I‚Äôd seeded in sap.capire.incidents-Incidents.csv.
After days of chasing ghosts, it all came down to a UI checkbox.

5 ‚Äì Lessons Learned

  • Curly quotes and BOMs: BAS sneaks them in; CAP chokes on them. Type the using ... from "../db/schema"; line manually.
  • Deploy both models (db, srv), not just the schema.
  • Use a real SQLite file in package.json; in-memory DBs reset on each run.
  • That ‚ÄúAdd Columns‚Äù message isn‚Äôt an error. It‚Äôs Fiori Elements politely saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôm empty until you tell me what to show.‚Äù

6 ‚Äì Takeaway

Sometimes CAP isn‚Äôt broken ‚Äî it‚Äôs just very literal. Between invisible characters, hidden tables, and silent checkboxes, getting to that first visible row can feel absurd. But once you‚Äôve fought through it, you understand how the layers fit together:

Layer Purpose

db/Entities and persistence
srv/OData service / projections
app/Fiori Elements UI
package.jsonThe glue holding it together

So when someone in the forums says ‚ÄúMy CAP service returns nothing,‚Äù you‚Äôll smile knowingly and reply: ‚ÄúCheck your quotes. Then click Add Columns.‚Äù

entry.title: Material Interchangeability During Goods Receipt
entry.content:
Material interchangeability in SAP MM allows users to substitute or replace materials in purchasing documents. This functionality enables flexibility in procurement processes, allowing purchase requisitions to be created with one material number and replaced with another that has similar characteristics during quotation or while posting goods receipt.

let's discuses the process for exchange during goods receipt

Define Manufacturer Part no. Indicator

Path: SPRO > Logistic General > Material Master > Basic Setting > Make Global Setting >
Set the "Manufacturer part no" indicator: Enable

 

 

 

Define manufacturer part profiles
‚Ä¢ Path: SPRO > Material Management > Purchasing > Material Master > Define manufacture part profile

  • Action: Create a profile and select the "Inventory-Managed Manuf. Part." indicator. This profile will be assigned to all interchangeable materials > then Save.

 

 

 

Define settings for material replacement in MIGO.

  • Path: SPRO > Logistic General > Interchangeability of parts > Define Settings for Material Exchange and Restricted Interchangeability
  • Action: Double-click on the "ME-MIGO-MIGO_GI" entry and configure the settings for automatic material exchange during goods receipt. When finished, the "Automatic material exchange" column for MIGO will be changed to "Yes"

 

 

 

And same for Migo_GR

Note: if you did not find MIGO_GR you can add it form New Entries

 

Set up screen for material replacement in goods movement.

  • Path: SPRO > Logistic General > Interchangeability of parts > setup screen for material replacement in goods movement
  • Action: Add your profile and assign the relevant users and plants

 

 

                   Important note : you need to add authorization object to your user profile ‚ÄúM_PIC_EXCH‚Äù

 

Create FFF Class Material >> MM01

Material type: FFFC

Select basic data 1

Assign manufacturer part profile and bas unit of measure

 

 

 

 

Create your own materials (Raw, Spare parts, etc...) with required views and assign Mfr Part Profile on purchasing view

Create interchangeability materials with material type ( HERB )

Here mfr part number is mandatory and it will same material number

Fill the required data and assign Mfr Part Profile on purchasing view

 

 

MPN Interchangeability Set Creation. Tcode >> PIC01

Insert material with FFF Class as created before

 

 

 

Assign main and interchangeability materials and save

 

click on MPN-MPR sets icon/tab

Maintain set ( plant ‚Äì MRP Area ‚Äì Materials )

Set check box for leading material ( main item ) then save

 

 

Now you can Create :

  • Info record for interchangeability materials
  • Create Purchase Order with Main Item

 

Po created with main item

 

Create a goods receipt reference to purchase order through MIGO

Now material exchange tab has been applied ... click on tab

 

 

 

Enter the required qty for main or interchangeability materials or both

Click Post

 

 

Material document posted

Let‚Äôs check the po

 

System has created 2 new line items first for remaining qty and another one for interchangeability material with price form info record

Should you have any questions regarding this document, please do not hesitate to reach out
I hope you find this document helpful

entry.title: Re: SAC: Unable to open private Bookmark after story conv...
entry.content:
@Dustin as you said it works for your colleague and not you, I am taking a wild guess that it could be a caching issue. 

  1. Try clearing your browser cache, using a different browser or incognito mode to see if that fixes the issue. 
  2. Try making a small edit to the story like changing a chart title, or moving a chart a little and then saving the story. This is what the error message tells you by "Please try refreshing the story, modifying the story and trying again". When you make a change and save the story, the stories metadata gets refreshed and sometimes that fixes some of these issues. 
  3. If these steps do not work, open a support incident with SAP Support, referencing SAP Note 3409867.

entry.title: Alternative Process for Reverse Factoring in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition without Scope Item 4AV
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I have a question regarding the implementation of a reverse factoring process in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

**Background:**
- Customer uses reverse factoring (supply chain finance)
- Dedicated scope item 4AV has been scoped out based on customer requirements
- Manual workaround using standard apps and postings is preferred

**Business Flow:**
1. Invoice received from supplier: ¬•1,000,000 (accounts payable created)
2. Customer requests reverse factoring from factoring company
3. Factoring company pays supplier: ¬•950,000 (¬•50,000 factoring fee deducted from supplier)
4. Customer pays factoring company on extended payment date: ¬•1,000,000

**Proposed Accounting Entries:**

1. AP creation (Feb 10):
DR: Expense 1,000,000
CR: Accounts Payable (Supplier account) 1,000,000
‚Üí App: Supplier Invoicing (MIRO equivalent)

2. Factoring company pays supplier (Feb 15):
DR: Accounts Payable (Supplier account) 1,000,000
CR: Accounts Payable (Factoring company account) 1,000,000
‚Üí App: Manual Journal Entry (FB01 equivalent)?
*Or should this clear the supplier AP and create a new AP to factoring company?*

3. Payment to factoring company on extended due date (Apr 30):
DR: Accounts Payable (Factoring company account) 1,000,000
CR: Bank 1,000,000
‚Üí App: Post Outgoing Payments (F-53 equivalent)

**Questions:**

1. Is this flow technically feasible in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition? Are the App IDs I mentioned correct, or should I use different apps?

2. What is the correct way to handle the AP transfer from supplier to factoring company in step 2? Should I:
- Use manual journal entry to transfer AP between vendors?
- Clear supplier AP and create new AP document for factoring company?
- Use a different approach?

3. How should we manage the factoring fee (¬•50,000)? Should it be:
- Recorded separately when payment occurs?
- Included in the initial AP transfer entry?
- Not recorded by customer at all (since supplier bears the cost)?

4. Are there any special master data settings required for reverse factoring suppliers (e.g., payment terms, vendor account groups, or other configurations)?

5. If this approach is not possible, what alternative process would you recommend? Please include:
- Which apps to use (with App IDs if possible)
- Accounting entries for each step
- Master data setup requirements

Any guidance would be greatly appreciated!

Best regards
